text: March 17, 2005 - Rules Committee Democrats Call..
label: HH3

text: Rules Committee Democrats Call
label: BODY

text: For Hearings on House Ethics
label: HH1

text: Ranking Member, Rep. Louise M. Slaughter Critical of Rampant Conflicts of Interest
label: HH3

text: Washington, DC - Led by Ranking Member, Rep. Louise M. Slaughter (D-NY-28), Democratic
label: BODY

text: members of the House Committee on Rules today called on Republican Chairman David Dreier
label: BODY

text: to hold hearings on House Ethics, and specifically on H. Res. 131, a bipartisan proposal to
label: BODY

text: restore the ethics complaint process after it was unilaterally gutted by the Republican leadership
label: BODY

text: at the beginning of the 109
label: BODY

text: th Congress.
label: BODY

text: "The House Ethics process is broken and its time to fix it," said Rep.
label: BODY

text: Slaughter. She added "
label: BODY

text: The Rules Committee must take this issue up and show once and for all that we are
label: BODY

text: committed to the integrity and honor of this House.
label: HH1

text: "
label: BODY

text: Although H. Res. 131 would typically be referred to the Subcommittee on Rules & the
label: BODY

text: Organization of the House, which is chaired by Rep. Hastings of Washington, the Democratic
label: BODY

text: Members of the Committee have requested a full committee hearing instead, given the obvious
label: BODY

text: conflict-of-interest it would create for Rep. Hastings, whom the Republican leadership recently
label: BODY

text: made chairman of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct (Ethics Committee).
label: BODY

text: Rep. Slaughter, Ranking Member of the Rules Committee, the committee with jurisdiction over
label: BODY

text: the procedures of the Ethics Committee, has been a vocal opponent of the Republican
label: BODY

text: leadership's continued efforts to destroy the House Ethics process.
label: BODY

text: March 17, 2005 - Rules Committee Democrats Call..
label: HH3

text: "The Republican leadership of this Congress has engaged in a strategy of
label: BODY

text: retribution and whitewash for their own ethical shortcomings. They subverted the
label: HH1

text: integrity of the Ethics process and they must be stopped
label: HH1

text: ," said Rep.
label: BODY

text: Slaughter. She added,
label: BODY

text: uot;It is time to air this out publicly in the form of hearings. The public has a right to
label: BODY

text: know what a mess has been made of their government."
label: HH1

text: "Given that Chairman Dreier, Rep. Sessions and Rep. Cole of the Rules Committee
label: BODY

text: all supported gutting the Ethics process, and have each contributed $5,000 to Majority
label: HH1

text: Leader Tom DeLay's legal defense fund, holding these hearings becomes all the more
label: HH1

text: important. Mr. Dreier must demonstrate to the American people that the Rules Committee
label: HH1

text: Republicans will no longer place the political survival of an ethically challenged Majority
label: HH1

text: Leader above the integrity of the House
label: HH1

text: ," said Rep. Slaughter.
label: BODY

text: LETTER TO CHAIRMAN DREIER:
label: HH2

text: March 17, 2005
label: BODY

text: March 17, 2005 - Rules Committee Democrats Call..
label: HH3

text: Chairman David Dreier
label: BODY

text: House Committee on Rules
label: BODY

text: H-312, Capitol Building
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Dreier:
label: BODY

text: We are writing to request that the Rules Committee hold an original jurisdiction hearing on H.
label: BODY

text: Res. 131, a bipartisan proposal to restore the ethics complaint process to the one that existed
label: BODY

text: before the Republican leadership unilaterally changed it at the beginning of the 109th
label: BODY

text: Congress.  H. Res. 131, which currently has 204 co-sponsors, was referred to the Rules
label: BODY

text: Committee on March 1, 2005, but to this date, the Committee has taken no action on it.
label: BODY

text: Although this resolution should properly be referred to the Subcommittee on Rules & the
label: BODY

text: Organization of the House, which is chaired by Rep. Hastings of Washington, we request a full
label: BODY

text: committee hearing instead, given the conflict it would create for Rep. Hastings, whom the
label: BODY

text: Republican leadership recently made Chairman of the Committee on Standards of Official
label: BODY

text: March 17, 2005 - Rules Committee Democrats Call..
label: HH3

text: Conduct (Ethics Committee).  We ask for this hearing because it would give our committee an
label: BODY

text: opportunity to begin repairing the damage that has been done over the past few months to the
label: BODY

text: House ethics process.
label: BODY

text: When the House adopted the 109th Rules package on January 4, 2005 on a party-line vote, it
label: BODY

text: was the first time in the history of the House ethics process (which dates back to 1968) that the
label: BODY

text: House has changed its ethics rules without the involvement of both parties.  The two preceding
label: BODY

text: ethics rules reforms (in 1989 and 1997) were undertaken by bipartisan task forces that spent
label: BODY

text: months discussing and drafting new rules.  In 1997, for example, under Speaker Gingrich, the
label: BODY

text: House created the Task Force on Ethics Reform to address the problems that had appeared in
label: BODY

text: the ethics process during the 104
label: BODY

text: th Congress.  This
label: BODY

text: 12-person group (6 Republicans and 6 Democrats) worked for more than four months to draft
label: BODY

text: new rules, which they submitted to the full House for debate and approval in September, 1997.
label: BODY

text: Rep. Mollohan's resolution would repeal the three changes the 109th rules package made to
label: BODY

text: these 1997 rules.  Most importantly, his resolution would restore the so-called "45-day
label: BODY

text: rule" (also called the "automatic transmittal rule"), a procedural safeguard the
label: BODY

text: 1997 Task Force developed to handle the situation in which the Ethics Committee fails to act on
label: BODY

text: a properly-filed complaint within 45 days.  Under this rule, if the Committee did not act in 45
label: BODY

text: days, the complaint was automatically forwarded to an investigative subcommittee.
label: BODY

text: This 45-day rule was a cornerstone of the task force recommendations because it helped
label: BODY

text: ensure that a valid complaint would be judged on its merits and would not be stalled in the
label: BODY

text: committee due to partisan politics.  The 109th rules package substituted this safeguard with
label: BODY

text: what has been called the "automatic dismissal rule," which would allow 5 Committee
label: BODY

text: Members from one party to take no action for 45 days and thereby allow a properly-filed,
label: BODY

text: meritorious complaint to be automatically dismissed without further investigation.  As Ranking
label: BODY

text: March 17, 2005 - Rules Committee Democrats Call..
label: HH3

text: Member Mollohan recently noted, when the House considered a similar automatic dismissal rule
label: BODY

text: in 1997, it rejected it by a bipartisan vote of 236-181 (vote # 410, Sept. 18, 1997).
label: BODY

text: In short, the rules changes the Republican Leadership unilaterally imposed on January 4, 2005
label: BODY

text: destroyed the fundamental principle underlying the 1997 reforms and the consistent,
label: BODY

text: long-standing practice of the Ethics Committee---that the Committee's operations must always
label: BODY

text: be based on bipartisan consensus.  These rules changes have dealt a mortal blow to a process
label: BODY

text: whose goal, as the 1997 Task Force put it, is "a nonpartisan peer review system which
label: BODY

text: has the trust and confidence of both the Members and the American people."
label: BODY

text: We direct you to the words of the House's resident experts on the ethics process, the
label: BODY

text: Chairman and Ranking Member of the Ethics Committee in the 108th Congress.  During the
label: BODY

text: debate on the opening day of the 109
label: BODY

text: Congress, then-Chairman Hefley said:
label: BODY

text: I have had the privilege of serving on the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct since
label: BODY

text: 1997 and have had an additional responsibility as serving as chairman since 2001. And during
label: BODY

text: that time, I have learned one paramount lesson: ethics must be bipartisan. The ethics process
label: BODY

text: must be bipartisan. Ethics reform must be bipartisan, and the ethics committee must be
label: BODY

text: bipartisan...The ethics committee is a bipartisan committee that follows the evidence wherever
label: BODY

text: the evidence leads. Meaningful ethics reform must be genuinely bipartisan. To have a bipartisan
label: BODY

text: process, any significant change in the ethics rules must be made only after careful, thorough
label: BODY

text: bipartisan consideration, as was done in 1989 and 1997.   (Congressional Record, Jan. 4,
label: BODY

text: When he introduced H. Res. 131, Ranking Member Mollohan expressed almost the exact
label: BODY

text: same sentiments.  He said:
label: BODY

text: March 17, 2005 - Rules Committee Democrats Call..
label: HH3

text: Approval of this resolution, Mr. Speaker, is also necessary for one other reason, and that is to
label: BODY

text: affirm the long-standing principle in the House that major changes in the ethics rules and
label: BODY

text: procedures must be made on a bipartisan basis. When the House revisited its ethics rules and
label: BODY

text: procedures in both 1989 and 1997, the work was done through bipartisan task forces that gave
label: BODY

text: thoughtful consideration to proposals from all Members. In contrast, Mr. Speaker, the changes
label: BODY

text: made in the rules package adopted in January were made on a party line vote, with no input
label: BODY

text: whatsoever from anyone in the minority.  Approval of this resolution will be a critical step in
label: BODY

text: restoring the bipartisanship that is essential if there is to be a meaningful ethics process in the
label: BODY

text: House. (Congressional Record, March 1, 2005, p. H 832)
label: BODY

text: Hundreds of media reports have documented the Republican Leadership's push to alter the
label: BODY

text: ethics rules to protect Majority Leader Tom DeLay from scrutiny for his actions over the past
label: BODY

text: several years.  In the wake of two unanimous Ethics Committee actions concluding that Majority
label: BODY

text: Leader DeLay acted improperly on three separate occasions in the 108th Congress and a Texas
label: BODY

text: grand jury indictment against two of the Majority Leader's top aides, the Republican Leadership
label: BODY

text: undertook a systematic effort to shield Mr. DeLay from being scrutinized for his behavior.
label: BODY

text: Other than the changes in the 109th rules package we discuss in the section above, the
label: BODY

text: Republican Leadership jammed a rule through the Republican Conference that would have
label: BODY

text: allowed Majority Leader DeLay to keep his leadership post even if he were indicted of a crime
label: BODY

text: by a grand jury.  Even more shocking was the Republican Leadership's proposal to eliminate
label: BODY

text: the long-standing "general rule of conduct" in our House Rules that requires
label: BODY

text: Members to conduct themselves "in a manner which shall reflect creditably on the House
label: BODY

text: of Representatives."  Thankfully, the rank-and-file Members of the Republican Conference
label: BODY

text: eventually killed these ideas after public outcry.
label: BODY

text: The Republican Leadership did not seem to be deterred by this setback dealt by their
label: BODY

text: Republican colleagues, nor were they satisfied with the passage of the ethics rules on the first
label: BODY

text: day of the 109th Congress.  Since that time, they have purged the Ethics Committee of those
label: BODY

text: Republican Members who dared act in the best interests of the House, rather than the Majority
label: BODY

text: Leader.  Speaker Hastert recently removed Chairman Hefley and two other Republican
label: BODY

text: Members (Reps. LaTourrette and Hulshof) from the Ethics Committee because of their
label: BODY

text: March 17, 2005 - Rules Committee Democrats Call..
label: HH3

text: outspoken support for keeping the ethics rules from the 108
label: BODY

text: th Congress.  Within
label: BODY

text: weeks of this move, the new chairman of the committee, our Rules Committee colleague Rep.
label: BODY

text: Hastings of Washington, fired two long-time Ethics Committee professional staffers.
label: BODY

text: As you know, the Ethics Committee has not yet organized in the 109th Congress because the
label: BODY

text: Committee has not been able to get a majority vote to adopt the Committee's new rules.  We
label: BODY

text: think this stalemate is the direct result of the partisanship that the Republican Leadership has
label: BODY

text: brought to the ethics process over the past few months.
label: BODY

text: We think a good first step to begin repairing the damage to the ethics process would be a
label: BODY

text: hearing on H. Res. 131.  As the 1997 Task Force observed in its final report: "Reform of
label: BODY

text: the standards process in the House has always been conducted in a bipartisan manner."
label: BODY

text: We sincerely hope that the 109th Congress will not go down go down in history as the one that
label: BODY

text: ended this invaluable tradition.
label: BODY

text: We look forward to your response to our request.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: March 17, 2005 - Rules Committee Democrats Call..
label: HH3

text: Hon. Louise M. Slaughter, Ranking Member               Hon. James McGovern, M.C.
label: BODY

text: Hon. Alcee Hastings, M.C.                                          Hon. Doris Matsui, M.C.
label: BODY
